title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pregnant mother asda shop delivery driver refused help
story: Amy Natasha Botten, from Feltham, West London, was left breathless and swaying from side to side as she struggled to collect her goods.Video captures the driver raising his voice at Amy who begs him to help her with the last bit because my little boy is up there crying his eyes out.Amy said: Can you not be a decent person  I am heavily pregnant. You are just going to walk off and leave me with this now The driver, who cuts her off, replied: See, before you taking little much. One time I go. Okay no problem... but not like this.Amy also questioned why there were no more bags that she could put her goods in. But he shrugged his shoulders and continued to pack up his empty crates.Amy later posted the video of her ordeal on Facebook with the caption: This shouldnt be happening to anyone......bad health, lonely and elderly, disabled, pregnant!!It should NOT BE HAPPENING. Its called HOME delivery.I just had to carry £ monthly shop up two flights of stairs alone, pregnant with pelvic problems.No choice but to leave my son on his own crying.Feltham Asda gave me a bottle of champagne and some flowers and couldnt apologise enough for the driver not doing his job .She was quick to highlight Asdas commitment in which drivers are required to offer to take shopping into customers homes.An Asda spokesperson told Sun Online: “We always try to offer our customers great service but clearly we got it wrong on this occasion and we are truly sorry. This goes against our home shopping policies and we have offered our full apology to Ms Botten and are in contact with her to try and make amends.”

title: landlord grimsby west marsh house mess family
story: Along with leaving the house in a state of disarray, the evicted family apparently still owe £, in unpaid rent for the Grimsby property.Landlord Garry told GrimsbyLive that the family had ruined the kitchen and that  bags of waste had to be hauled from the house.The kitchen floor had nearly vanished under the piles of bags filled to the brim with filthy clothes, food containers caked in mould and white counters so stained that they had turned brown.It seemed the family had destroyed the garden too by leaving it to vastly overgrow with nettles and brambles and littering it with broken doors, cupboards and household waste.Carpets had been ripped up, doors were hanging off their hinges, electrical sockets had been knocked out of the walls and the bathroom was completely trashed.Garry said that he was forced to refurbish the entire house and that even the ceiling was covered in grime.According to the disgruntled landlord, the family were on Universal Credit and that this isnt the first time hes had issues with tenants on housing benefits.He was forced to evict one of his previous tenants, who was also on Universal Credit who owed him thousands in rent.His property manager, Anne, has said that it has completely put him off renting to people on benefits and that they have had numerous problems with them going into arrears.She said: Many times when a tenant goes onto the benefits system, there is no communication with us as landlords, and for the first few months we often get no rent paid.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Bremeridge Manor, in Dilton Marsh, Wiltshire dates back to  and was once the home of King Henry VIII, Queen Elizabeth I and King James I.The Grade II listed building is now up for grabs, but it could be hiding something very valuable indeed.In  a hoard of th century gold coins was discovered buried under the property when workmen were building an extension.It has been suggested that gold could still be lurking in the grounds waiting to be discovered.Guests can enter the grand property through a huge oak door thought to be over  years old and toast themselves by the same fireplace used by royalty.The house is surrounded by vast greenery with well-manicured lawns and trimmed trees, complete with its own lake.Unbelievably it is going for half the price of a Kensington flat with two bedrooms, bathroom and a living dining room.It has , sq ft of accommodation with a sitting room, dining room, kitchen breakfast room, drawing room, study, a main bedroom with en-suite bathroom and dressing room, another three bedrooms and two bathrooms.According to records, the manor was acquired by an order of monks, the Bonhommes of Edington, in .It was then passed to Henry VIII when he dissolved the monasteries between  and  and was then sold off to James Blount - Lord Mountjoy.He sold it back to the monarchy in  when it was bought by Queen Elizabeth I, who visited the nearby Longleat House in the same year.Previous owner Evan Morgans said: It was a few months after I had moved in that I began to research the history of the house.Its truly mind-boggling to discover that you can trace a history of continuous occupancy of your house from yourself, going back to  when the first recorded owner died.That is  years of knowing every owner, every lessee and every tenant. title: gp surgery worker mum hangs herself after losing job
story: Victoria Pocock, , killed herself while her partner and their infant son were asleep upstairs.The -year-old was found hanging at the bottom of the stairs by her partner, who quickly put their -month-old son back to bed before dialling .The coroner heard that the operator told James Smith to cut his partner down and to start CPR but despite his best efforts and those of paramedics who later arrived, she was declared dead at the scene in Lambourn, near Hungerford, Berkshire.The inquest heard how Miss Pocock had battled depression for a number of years and had recently lost her job at a GP surgery.A statement from Dr Christa Teplickywas read out by Senior Berkshire Coroner Heidi Connor.Dr Teplicky said: Miss Pocock had been employed by a cleaning company that worked at the GP surgery.“The last time she was seen as a patient at the clinic was on March , but she was seen afterwards in the evenings when she was cleaning.Her main complaint was that she struggled to sleep. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Luisa Fernanda, , from central Colombia, fell ill after the tattoo became infected and later suffered a miscarriage.Doctors told her that she would never walk again after the infection spread into her spinal cord.She underwent surgery to drain off some of the liquid caused by the infection but then developed problems with her appendix.Miss Fernanda said: As I had to take a lot of medicine, I had a miscarriage and lost the son I was carrying.She then needed further treatment to help her deal with depression caused by the loss of her baby.Miss Fernanda has now spoken out about her experiences on social media to warn other youngsters about the dangers of tattoos.A year ago I had a tattoo done and it caused the bacteria that affected the spinal cord and stopped me from walking again.It was hard when I was told by the surgeons that I would not able to walk again. My mum supported me a lot.And it was hard when I left hospital because I needed help to get in and out of my wheelchair and my mum is not strong enough.I was ashamed of being seen outside on the street, because people would point at me, but later I realised it was not good to stay at home all the time.Miss Fernanda added that surgeons had told her that she needed a further operation as she battles to regain her health.Her friends are helping her try to find the money to cover the cost of her £,treatment.

title: philip hammond crackdown web giants
story: Philip Hammond delighted Tory conference activists with his surprise vow to introduce a Digital Services Tax.The levy on international profits made from users in Britain by ­Calornia-based giants such as Facebook and Google will recoup hundreds of millions of pounds.Mr Hammond wants it in place in one to two yearsa global agreements on taxing tech firms still ­cannot be reached. The crowd-pleaser was the gem of his keynote speech to the Tories’ annual conference in Birmingham.But he also used it to spell out a vision to harness the unfolding technology revolution to improve angry Brits’ lives. If was Mr Hammond’s rival offer to defeat hard-left Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn’s Socialist blueprint.Mr Hammond told the conference: “Global internet giants must contribute fairly to funding our public services. The best way to tax international companies is through international agreements.“But the time for talking is coming to an end and the stalling has to stop. If we cannot reach agreement, the UK will go it alone with a Digital Services Tax of its own.”The Chancellor will push ahead with the move after losing patience with the US.Despite repeated promises for global action to end the tax dodge, President Trump’s administration is still stalling on a solution as it reaps billions from the firms, with so many based on the US’s West Coast.Britain is instead now looking at Europe-wide action, as France is also keen for something to be done. The Treasury is also consulting on a second online levy, an Online Sales Tax, to force digital retailers such as Amazon to pay more tax too.But sources close to the Chancellor said he is going cold on that as he fears the giants will just pass it straight on to consumers.The Cabinet has been under heavy pressure to combat Mr Corbyn’s polished offer of Socialist solutions to angry voters’ woes during a successful Labour conference last week.Mr Hammond tackled the Labour boss head-on yesterday, by pledging to “harness the power of the market economy” instead of “a discredited ideology that will never solve real-world problems”.He insisted Tories must face up to the anger among many British workers, saying: “Too many feel they are working for the system, but the system isn’t working for them.“So our challenge is to ensure st-century capitalism delivers for those people. It will be this technological transformation, and how we manage it — not Brexit — that will define the future of our country and our party.”Mr Hammond added: “Show them that, crucially, the change that technology is driving will address their concerns, not make them worse.“If we look for a moment like the party of “no change”, then we should not be surprised that some will be tempted by the dangerous populism of our opponents.”Mr Hammond also answered the calls of big business who have been stung by PM Theresa May’s attack on excess profits and boardroom culture. Tory donor and City billionaire Michael Spencer said the party had “lost its way” on business, accusing the PM of “letting herself down”.But the Chancellor said: “Let me say it, loud and clear: the Conservative Party is, and always will be, the party of business. title: budget must put money in pockets

title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesia earthquake flores days after tsunami sulawesi island latest
story: The quake, which hit about  miles southwest of Ende on Flores, was later downgraded to a magnitude of ..There were no immediate tsunami alerts or reports of casualties or damage.It comes after the true scale of the devastation caused by the Indonesian tsunami and earthquake was been revealed in harrowing images.Aerial footage shows the extent of the damage caused by the magnitude . earthquake that sparked ft-high tsunami waves and killed up to ,.Search-and-rescue teams combed destroyed homes and buildings in Palu including a collapsed eight-story hotel, for any trapped survivors, but they needed more heavy equipment to clear the rubble.Many people were believed trapped under shattered houses in Palus Balaroa neighbourhood, where the earthquake caused the ground to heave up and down violently.In Petobo a village on the citys outskirts, the quake caused loose, wet soil to liquefy, creating a thick, heavy mud that caused massive damage.In Petobo, it is estimated that there are still hundreds of victims buried in mud, said disaster agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho.The focus has now shted to burying the dead and providing food and shelter for the thousands left homeless by the earthquake.The dead have begun to be placed side-by-side in a -metre mass grave dug for , bodies.Britain has launched a £million rescue mission to provide help to the devastated area.The -metre-long dirt and rubble trench has been dug in Palu and can be enlargedneeded, said Willem Rampangilei, chief of Indonesias National Disaster Mitigation Agency.Most of the dead are from Palu, on the island of Sulawesi, where the tsunami crashed onto the shoreline as thousands had gathered for a beach festival at dusk last Friday.The city was a crumpled mess of houses, cars and trees mashed together by the magnitude-. quake, with rooftops and roads split and left at all angles.What we know so far:The mass burial of earthquake and tsunami victims had to be carried out as soon as possible for health and religious reasons, said the disaster mitigation agency.Indonesia is a majority Muslim country, and religious custom calls for burials soon after death, typically within one day.Army Commander Tiopan Aritonang said  bodies would be transferred from one hospital alone to the  metres-by--metrestrench in Palu.All of the victims have been photographed to help families locate where their relatives were buried.Residents trying to track down their loved ones have been walking from body bag to body bag, opening the top to check who is wrapped inside.After volunteers laid bodies inside the trench, mechanical earth-movers pushed soil on top of them.It is also feared that about , people are dead after mudslides swamped villages further inland, with Petobo resident Yusuf Hasmin telling the Jakarta Post that mud rolled in like waves.The area was hit by soil liquefaction, when severe shaking from such a strong earthquake turns earth into mud.The phenomenon occurs when loose water-filled soil near the surface loses its strength and collapses.Nugroho said authorities estimate that there are still hundreds of victims buried in mud in Petobo. Rescue teams are trying to dig the victims out.About  Indonesian troops were today expected to join about , personnel – including military and police – to help rescue efforts in Palu and Donggala.They are bringing food, water and other supplies to the affected area,Search and rescue spokesman Sutopo Purwo Nugroho said most of the  foreigners visiting Palu at the time of the disaster have been accounted forBut one South Korean is believed to be trapped in Roa-Roa Hotel, while three others from France and one from Malaysia are still missing.Rescuers have also managed to free a -year-old girl, Nurul Istikharah, who was unable to move her legs, as she was trapped under concrete beside her dead mother and niece.Istikharah was unconscious during part of the effort to free her, but rescuers kept talking to her to try to keep her awake.Nearly all the disaster’s deaths have been recorded in Palu, which has a population of ,, but  fatalities have been recorded nearby in Donggala.The city is built around a narrow bay that magnied the force of the tsunami waters as they raced into the tight inlet.Aid and supplies have been sent in via military and commercial aircraft, including helicopters, to reach badly affected areas.Donggala, the site closest to the earthquakes epicentre, and Mamuju were also ravaged, but little information has been available to victims due to damaged roads and disrupted telecommunications.Desperate survivors have been forced to loot shops for basics like food, water and fuel as police looked on, unwilling or unable to intervene. Meanwhile, government officials said some , inmates fled at least three prisons in the region.Residents were also seen ing to their destroyed homes, picking through waterlogged belongings, trying to salvage anything they could find.Others chose to flee the city and with roads soon becoming clogged with traffic jams.Dwi Haris, who suffered a broken back and shoulder in the chaos, broke down as she described the ordeal.There was no time to save ourselves. I was squeezed into the ruins of the wall, I think, she said.I heard my we cry for help, but then silence. I dont know what happened to her and my child. I hope they are safe.Associated Press reports that when the . quake hit just after pm on Friday, the meteorology and geophysics agency issued a tsunami alert, warning of potential for waves of . to three metres .But it was heavily criticised for ending the warning too soon, at .pm, particularly as the waves were considerably higher.The tsnumai was the latest natural disaster to hit Indonesia, which is frequently struck by earthquakes, volcanic eruptions because of its location on the Ring of Fire, an arc of volcanoes and fault lines in the Pacic Basin.In December , a massive magnitude . earthquake off Sumatra island in western Indonesia triggered a tsunami that killed , people in a dozen countries.Last month, a powerful quake on the island of Lombok killed  people.

title: tupac shakur helped to cuba fidel castro brit michael nice
story: The Hit Em Up rapper was famously shot on the Las Vegas strip back in  as he was leaving a Mike Tyson fight, aged just  years old.Since then, conspiracy theories that he actually survived the shooting and faked his death have continued to spread – including a photo that emerged on the internet last year.Now Michael Nice - who last month claimed he was part of security team tasked with helping Tupac escape Las Vegas - reckons the rapper made it to Cuba thanks to the late leader.He said: I have audio and video evidence of Fidel Castro confirming he sanctioned Tupac to live in Cuba.And he sanctioned the double body switch that I was involved in.There were terms and conditions on that sanction. There was a limit to the amount of time. There were conditions on his behaviour. He must not confess to actually be in Cuba.Michael previously told TMZ: Why you think nobody been arrestedthey said they the one that killed Tupac He added: Because Tupac is not dead. If he was dead, they’d be arresting those dudes for murder.You know he’s somewhere smoking a Cuban cigar on an island.Michael claims he was party of the security team for The Black Panthers political party in the s.He says the group heard about a hit being put out on the Changes singer - and the order went out to get him to a hiding place.Michael says the rapper was only injured on September , , and was rushed out of the country.He said: It was me, my brother, the pilot, Tupac as the co-pilot and two Panther guys on the jet.We took off and immediately knew we were safe, we felt good and it was like escaping from prison.There were hugs and handshakes when we finally managed to get him to Barbados.Michael added: Then my brother helped him get to Cuba from there.[Fellow rapper] Kadafi was doing some kind of hand signals – he looked kind of funky.I saw them alive way after their said deaths.The latest sighting came after the internet went wild two years ago over claims Tupac had been photographed apparently living a new le in Cuba.Tupac was infamously gunned down on September , , while driving through Las Vegas. He died in hospital six days later.Numerous people - including fellow rapper Notorious BIG - were implicated in his death.But the identity of the chart-topper’s killer has remained a mystery for more than  years and no charges have ever been brought.One possible suspect, identied in  by an LA Times investigation, was Orlando Anderson, a member of the Southside Crips gang.It claimed that Shakur and several of their entourage had beaten up Anderson the same day as the shooting, but Las Vegas cops discounted the beating from their investigation.Anderson, who denied the claims, was later killed in a gang shooting in .Last year The Sun online revealed how the  director of another film which claims to have solved the murder mystery says LA cops hindered his long-running battle for justice.RJ Bond said some of the homicide detectives responsible for tracking down the rap stars cold-blooded killers had hidden agendas and seemed to have no interest in finding those really responsible.Bond had tracked down a confession letter said to have been written by one of the men responsible for opening fire on Tupacs Cadillac in .The US documentary maker and author claims the document names the killers and clears rap mogul Suge Knight of any involvement in the drive-by shooting.Suge tonight pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter and is set to serves  years behind bars.The letter - provided to the Sun Online by Bond - is said to have been written by one of the gunmen who opened fire on Tupacs car in Las Vegas.Meanwhile, Kadafi – real name Yafeu Akiyele Fula - was found slumped on the third floor stairwell of a New Jersey apartment block after being accidentally shot in the head.The culprit later turned himself in to the police and served seven years in prison for the crime.Got a story  email digishowbiz@the-sun or call us direct on   We pay for videos too Click here to upload yours. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: found most embarrassing event tory
story: NewsopinionI found the most embarrassing event at Tory conference and you almost certainly didnt see itJeremy Wright probably would have got a bigger crowd for his speechhe hadnt turned up - and that was originally the planShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT NewsopinionJeremy Wright addresses the masses "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailImagine you’re a Cabinet Minister. Now imagine being in the situation where more people would have turned up to see your speechyou hadn’t turned up yourself. That’s the position Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright was in this afternoon. You see, Jeremy was originally supposed to deliver his speech to Conservative Party Conference as a hologram. A projection. A digital apparition. It was the brainchild of his predecessor, Matt Hancock - now Health Secretary, and much more comfortable in the ‘Minister of Fun’ brief than Wright. You remember him. He’s the one who did Parkour.  And had his own app - called Matt Hancock - which wasn’t very good, but at the very least didn’t leak the Defence Secretary’s mobile number to literally anyone who wanted it. Before Theresa May’s last reshuffle, The Right Honourable Jeremy Wright QC was the attorney general. The government’s top lawyer.I’ve seen Wright deliver learned, competent speeches about tricky subjects like cyber security. He was quite good at it.Which made his move to Culture, where hed have to talk about sportand musiceven more baffling. But while the hologram stunt might have been infinitely better suited to Matt Hancocks talents, at least it would have given Jeremy a bit of pizazz. Wright, a curious charisma vacuum, took to the stage to tell an anecdote about his school play to a concert hall barely busier than the upper room was for the Last Supper. “When I was , I was shy and didnt much like being the centre of attention. I’ve changed,” he joked, fooling nobody. He went on: “But that year I was persuaded to take a large part in a school play. “The effect on my self-confidence, on what I felt I could do, was signicant and long-lasting. “So much so that I feel able to say to you thatI had not stood on that stage then, I would not be standing on this stage now.”  It’s hard to think that when Wright wrote those lines into his speech, he’d imagined delivering them them to a crowd which could have comfortably fit in the school hall which saw his theatrical debut. A conservative estimate - pun intended - put the size of the party faithful somewhere just south of , scattered through the four levels of Birmingham’s cavernous Symphony Hall. I genuinely just went into the hall to see how sparse the crowd was, but so empty was the auditorium I almost felt obliged to keep my seat until the end of his address to make up the numbers. It’s not just him, though he was the most pathetic example. There were plenty of seats free for Chancellor Philip Hammond’s speech. There was no compunction to turn up early for Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, or even Tory conference favourite Ruth Davidson, who gave a speech which hit all the right notes, but was never going to win a Grammy.

title: tory dominic raab admits no
story: NewsTory Dominic Raab admits No Deal Brexit could be used to hand corporations a massive tax cutDominic Raab said the government will “pull every lever weve got” to ease business “disruption”the UK leaves the EU with no agreement in March ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDominic Raab has an opportunity - but will it be one for big business  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tory ministers could hand corporate giants a massive tax cut in a No Deal Brexit , a top Cabinet figure revealed tonight.Dominic Raab said the government will “pull every lever weve got” to ease business “disruption”the UK leaves the EU with no agreement in March . The Brexit Secretary even left open a radical idea of slashing corporation tax from % to % - which would firms a huge tax break while millions of working families struggle. He spoke on the fringes of the Tory conference hours after Chancellor Philip Hammond said he was reserving “fiscal firepower” to “support the economy” in No Deal Brexit.  Mr Raab was asked his view on an idea by Chloe Westley, of the right-wing TaxPayers Alliance think tank, of dropping corporation tax to % - and using tax to get a “post-Brexit boom”. The Cabinet minister replied: “You just said Chloe wants to reduce corporation tax to % - and the Chancellors talked about reserving fiscal firepower in the case of no deal. “What more do you want  “Of course hes talking about the recognition that actually, in the no deal scenario, we want to pull every lever weve got to see us through what short term buffeting or disruption we have. “I think the Chancellor gave a brilliant speech and it shows you were all rowing the same boat.”  Mr Raab is a free marketeer who in  proposed scrapping the minimum wage for some under-s. Indicating other Cabinet ministers may back his view, Mr Raab laughed and added: “People were coming to this conference expecting it to be dynamite. “Actually now the journalists are all complaining to me that theres not really much going on, there seems to be far too much of people singing from the same hymn sheet.” “I think the Chancellor gave a great speech, not just talking about what we would do in no deal, but talking about the advantages economically for the countrywe get the Chequers deal across the line.” It comes days after Theresa May pledged to cut Brexit Britains corporation tax rate to the lowest in the G – a title currently held by Singapore on %. Tory governments have already slashed the rate from % in . With weeks left to secure a deal, Mr Raab suggested EU chiefs had “weaponised” the deadlock over the Irish border to get leverage. “I think there has been a bit of that,” he said. “There is no doubt there are some that have enjoyed politicising this issue – I say enjoyed, have taken the opportunity.”

title: what tory brexit going look
story: NewsopinionThis is what the Tory Brexit is going to look likeTheres bad news for borders, badgers and BorisShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are  days until Brexit, theyve got a full tank of prats, half a pack of loons, theyre doomed and theyre wearing blue rosettes. Welcome to the Conservative Party conference of , where the Tories are trying to pretend they can organise a knees-up that doesnt somehow end in whacking themselves in the testicles.Its day one, and theyve already failed. Their Great Blond Hope has not only been victim of a Big Daddy splash by Lord Digby Jones, hes been impersonated by Phil Voldemort Hammond and had his ideas characterised as not much good by David Mine Are No Better Davis.We are now uncomfortably close to the arbitrary date for leaving the European Union, chosen by a Prime Minister who herself was chosen because she wasnt someone , and as is the way with things on horizons it looks worryingly like an out-of-control hydrogen explosion.We all know whats happened - the referendum supposed to uny the Tories has caused them to turn on each other like cannibals who gave up chlorinated chicken for Lent, the question supposed to be settled for a generation remains unanswered, and Theresa May is still PM primarily because she isnt someone .So what is Brexit going to look like, under the Tories  . Project Oh Dear Jeremy Hunt is a man who has more in common with an Anglepoise lamp than the rest of the human race. He can be pointed, turned on, and turned off again, but usually fails to illuminate anyone. Or that the USSR, which invaded countries that tried to leave it and killed millions, is just like the EU, which negotiates, even with people who dont know what theyre doing. . To do so they are relying on a referendum they say must be respected, while ignoring a referendum they say must be over-ridden.All the people concerned were told beforehand that Brexit would spell the end of the Good Friday Agreement, a hard-won peace in Northern Ireland, and possibly the end of the Union altogether. That they have now,  months from doom, had this explained to them again by a comedian shows just what a bad joke the Tories are.Patrick Kieltys dad was murdered by the Ulster Freedom Fighters for exposing their organised crime. Project It All Onto Someone Else Presiding over economic chaos  Watching John Lewis go down the pan, the world turn against you, and Jacob Rees-Mogg destroying all his own suggestions by moving his investment funds to the EU and trying to get a trade deal with the Peoples Republic of Jam Jar Or Something Like That  Well, why not shoot some more badgers. title: glamour model reveals trade secrets
story: NewsGlamour model and former lap dancer, , reveals the secrets of the tradeTanya Cox, from Hull, has been working in the industry for  years and says shes now breaking into the mature market of glamour modellingShareCommentsBySophie CorcoranSophie Kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsTanya Cox, , has revealed the trade secrets of working as a glamour model "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA glamour model has revealed the secrets of the trade from what working on shoots is really like to meeting women who start modelling topless in their s. Tanya Cox, , from Hull, has been working in the industry since she was  but says she often thinks about getting a real job. She was scouted as a glamour model while working as a lap dancer and says her past experience enabled her to be comfortable in front of the camera. Despite loving her job, Tanya says she thought about giving up her career when jobs dried up after she turned , reports the Hull Daily Mail. However, shes now finding success again as she breaks into the mature market. How did you get into modelling and was it something you always wanted to do  I never really thought about doing any modelling work but whilst I was working as a lap dancer, I got approached by an agency and was askedI would consider doing any modelling work. I was quite shocked as I thought you had to be tall and skinny to do any kind of modelling but they reassured me that was just the fashion industry and that I was perfect for glamour. How old were you and how long have you been doing it  I came into the industry at  and I’m now . What was it like at first and what kind of things you were doing  Having already worked as a lap dancer for three years, I was very comfortable with modelling straight away. I think its the taking your clothes off bit that worries most new glamour models but as I had already been doing that for three years, that was the easy part, it was learning to find the light and what angles suited me that took the time the learn. Was you aware of any challenges the industry faced at the beginning  No, when I first came into the industry, everything seemed great, people were much more reliable with higher standards always putting quality first back then. But now its more quantity over quality and trying to get as much as possible shot in the time frame are booked for. Was there ever a point where you regretted getting into modelling  When I first turned , my work really quietened off as some companies considered me too old for the young market but I still looked too young to break the mature market. It was a very low point in my le and feeling my career slip away made me so depressed at times that I wished I never started. What has been the best things about it  Are there any moments which stand out where you loved it  I think for me, it helped me to find my own inner strength. I was guilty of never sticking up for myself when I was younger but now Im the first to say when anyone is out of order, whether its towards myself, a friend or even a stranger. Also through modelling and dancing, I have now met the best friends that I have ever had. I trust them completely and never doubt anymore that they all love me, as much as I love them. What has been some of the worst things about it  The worst thing about modelling is the high cancellation rates which has been getting worse and worse each year since , but I dont think that is just an industry problem, I think society in general has forgotten its manners because I have noticed that more and more people cancel social meets with friends than ever before too.  Have you ever been judged based on your career  What do you think of that  Not in my personal le, but since my work started to quieten off and I have been trying to get a normal job, I do feel like employers are discriminating against me as I dont even seem to be able to get an interview these days, and when I was younger I always found it so easy to get work. When a place I worked at closed down, I had a new job within a week. How successful have you been  I felt pretty successful when I was younger but I do think I would of had a better career had I started when I was younger as it only lasted a few years before my peak ran out. I am now just starting to finally break the mature market, so fingers crossed I can make a success of that, but early days yet. Modelling must have changed since you started - have you seen that and in what way  It certainly has, all the technology keeps changing, I dont know how the photographers keep up. And unfortunately the budgets arent as big anymore. I really miss the days of make-up artists and clothing departments on all shoots, but these days its only the very biggest companies that provide those now and for most shoots we just get a list of what types clothing to bring with us and have to do our own hair and make-up. Do you think it will change in the future and in what way  We are seeing dferent types of models coming through now We are and I love that we are now celebrating ersity with models now coming in dferent shapes, sizes, styles and ages. I met a new model on set recently who had just started doing topless modelling at . Social media has also come to the forefront and many models experience trolling - is that something youve experienced  Yes, I have had a few negative comments but, for every bad comment I get, there is always at least  positive comments to counter-act it and the troll then usually ends up getting loads of grief for his her comment anyway so it always back fires on them.  Would you advise someone to get into the industry  What would your advice be and how would they go about getting a break  Although when times are good, its not just a job to me, it is my le and I do love modelling but because of how dficult I have found trying to find a normal job since, no I wouldnt recommend anyone getting into the industry. Butsomeone is  per cent certain that its what they want to do, I recommend joining the online portfolio sites over an agency so you can speak to the photographers you are shooting for direct yourself as the agencies dont always give you the right information. Just make sure you always check references and remember you should never do anything that your not comfortable with. Is age a big thing in modelling and have you ever felt stigmatised by others in the industry  There is definitely more work for younger models, but thanks to films like American Pie making MILFS, GILFS and Cougars sexy, it has opened up the industry to mature models too which is great but the down side is that once your above , everyone feels the need to point out the fact that your older by using the terms MILF Cougar etc alongside all your publications. I am still struggling with this eight years on as I keep getting called a MILF and find the term really offensive. Looking back now, do you feel empowered by it all  I feel that the industry has helped me to realise that it is OK to just be myself and that my imperfections make me human, approachable and more relatable. What agency are you with  Im not with any agencies anymore. They did help get me work when I was new but once you are established, the bookings come to you direct and I also had a problems with been given the wrong information and been sent on jobs for levels I dont cover.

story: NewsOnly Fools and Horses fan spends £k converting narrowboat into Del Boys Reliant Regal vanTony Vaughan was inspired to transform his ft canal boat after a pals suggestion at the pub - and four pints of GuinnessShareCommentsByJoe PagnelliJames SpeakmanChris kitching:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video the-trotters-independent-traders-barge-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Only Fools and Horses fan has spent pound, to convert his narrowboat into Del Boys iconic Reliant Regal from the hit sitcom. Tony Vaughan was inspired to transform his ft canal boat after a pals suggestion at the pub last September - and four pints of Guinness. Retired engineer Tony, , snapped up the canary yellow vehicle shell for pound and spent six hours a day for a month converting the boat into a vehicle the wheeler dealer himself would be proud of. Tony, from Stockport, Greater Manchester, said: Making this Only Fools boat has been a laugh for me, Ive absolutely loved it.  I love seeing the smiles on peoples faces when they see my boat come through. If you watch one episode of the show and then watch it a couple weeks after you see something youve missed. So theres always something new to discover - the one liners are so smartly written and I just love it. Trigger is quite amusing because wherever he comes on he says alright Dave  I always laugh at that. The show just makes me laugh. If somebody doesnt laugh at Only Fools and Horses theres something seriously wrong with them.  Dad-of-four Tony bought the boat for pound, eight years ago and has splashed out a further pound, modernising it. Tony said: When I bought the boat it was already called Trotters Independent and we had so many comments when we were in Derbyshire that I decided to keep the boats name. When my mate suggested putting a car on it after Id had four pints of Guinness I thought it wasnt a terrible idea. Two months later Id started looking for a car to put on the back of my boat. Grandad-of-four Tony tracked down a seller from Haywood, Staffordshire, flogging the shell of a yellow Reliant Robin who wanted to keep the engine.  Tony said: I struggled to find a car because some people didnt like what I was going to do with the car. I came across a car for sale where this chap wanted the engine and I just wanted the body, so we came to an arrangement and I ended up with the body of the car. Tony had help at the weekends from boat builder stepson Richard Pemberton, , who joined him for eight hours a day helping to renovate the boat. It involved measuring the boat and assessing which elements of the car would fit. Tony said: All the work was quite technical, which is why I had to get Richard involved as he knows how to build boats. There was a lot of work to do between cutting things, welding and working with fibreglass.  It still had to look like the car, so the bonnet at the front is on the same plane as the back. Its just exactly the way it was when it was a car - just a bit longer and with a boat in between. The most exhausting and dficult thing was to work in between the weather because youre on the canal, so you really feel its effects. He added: The wind and rain can be scary. I nearly fell into the canal a few times barely holding on to parts of the boat, but falling into the canal would have been worth it to get this done. I was determined to get it done and the boat kept getting better and better, so it wasnt dficult to motivate myself to keep working. The more I work on it the more ideas pop into my head as well. Ive just installed a new tiller system, which makes it easier to steer, but I wont be adding any more Only Fools and horses additions. I think its all sorted now.  Tony bought the narrowboat eight years ago and moved into it permanently a year later. His partner of  years, Pamela Allen, , joins him at the weekends but doesnt live on the boat with him. Tony said: I live on the boat and have been living on it for the past seven years. I love it because I get my peace and quiet, and thankfully I never get sea sick. Ive got everything in my boat that youd have in a house. My home essentials include my fire, central heating, cooker oven, microwaves, fridge, and obviously Guinness. I moved into the boat because I got fed up of living in a house. Ive wanted to do this for about  years, and I thought Im not getting any younger andI dont do it now I never will.

title: women closing infidelity gap more
story: NewsWomen are closing the infidelity gap: Why more and more wives are cheating on their husbandsIncreasing numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men -despite still loving their other halves, an author claimsShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  OCT News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Couple-in-bed.jpg" More and more women are said to be cheating on their spouses"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWomen are closing the infidelity gap, experts believe.More and more females are said to be rejecting monogamy and cheating on their spouses - despite saying they still love them.They are now reportedly more likely to cheat than three decades ago, with increased autonomy, earning power and opportunity. Women are  per cent more likely now to cheat on their husbands than in , says best-selling author, Wednesday Martin. She adds that it appears rising numbers of women are prepared to act on their thoughts of other men, despite being in marriages. Wednesday, whose new book Untrue is out this month, came across a number of real women’s voices and stories when carrying out research. In a piece for the Daily Mail , she describes how one woman, called Erica, didnt want to give up on her marriage when the passion disappeared.Instead, after years of sexual disappointment, the -year-old went online to search for someone - and ended up having a passionate affair. Wednesday says the women she encountered had ying problems, from routine sex that didnt fulfil them, to no intimacy, to a craving for novelty. Crucially, none of these women wanted to give up on their marriages or loved their husbands any less, explains the author. While male infidelity used to be at a much higher rate than female infidelity, experts believe the gap is increasingly narrowing. One reason is that more women are out at work, where they are apart from their partners and exposed to potential lovers, some experts say. Another reason could be technology - with women able to discreetly have affairs through social media and apps, according to Wednesday.  And some believe women in long-term relationships are just as likely to lose interest in their other halves over time as men are. Wednesday says that what she has discovered through research is that women’s libidos are far stronger and more adventurous than we thought. Her research included speaking to women of a range of ages, as well as investigating scientic and evolutionary theories. In her Mail article, she says some scientists believe women get bored of sleeping with the same man, and desire others, for evolutionary reasons. They need new experiences to stay interested, according to these scientists. According to Wednesdays book, female infidelity is now far from uncommon. In it, the author writes: Women lust and women cheat. And it sets us aflame.
