title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of #Csaba out# rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United#s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprisehe is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on  minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird#s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals # often carbon copies of each other.The second came on  minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On  minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on  minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay#s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on  minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United#s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba Full details in live blog.

title: bumper year for cruises as travel firmscapitalise ondundee buzz
story: Dundee’s cruise liner chief says the city has enjoyed a bumper year of arrivals bolstered by locals working together to create unforgettable experiences for tourists. vw, px"  Robert Mason, head of cruise at Capital Cruising, said the city’s public bodies, trading associations and local businesses were all keen to make the most of the city’s incoming visitors.He said: “For us, it’s about sustaining the growth and making the most of what Dundee has to offer, working with all of our partners and local businesses to link the port with the city.“Everyone is keen to work with us at the port because Dundee is a very exciting opportunity at the moment.“We’re grateful for all the support that we’ve got to facilitate the cruise business here.”The number of ships docking in Dundee continues to trend higher than in the past.In all, Dundee welcomed  ships to its harbour in , and  the year before.That’s compared with  ships in  and just six in . The dozen-plus boats now calling in Dundee each year are bringing between up to , passengers into the city throughout the season.Ships such as the Seabourn Ovation, the Albatros, Crystal Serenity and the Pacic Princess hold anywhere from  to , passengers at a time.And as Dundee goes from strength to strength, the city’s port has been able to establish fresh partnerships with bodies such as VA Dundee.Mr Mason continued: “We have nine calls confirmed for next year at the moment.“In the market Dundee is seen as quite an ‘opportunistic’ port because there’s a lot of buzz around it at the moment.“You also get a lot of cruises from all over – the Baltics, up to the Faroes, Greenland, just about all of Western Europe. It’s in a very good position.“The berth in the city is also very accommodating, in that it is a city centre port and it can take on several ships.“We had three ships here for the Open, which really drove ships and stopovers in Dundee.“We had another two here for the VA and organised group visits to the museum.“We’ve been welcoming people in with pipe bands, and Dundee and Angus College students have been acting as local guides with knowledge of things like where to find a church on a Sunday.”The hundreds of people who disembark at Dundee provide a much-welcome boost to the local economy in the city and in Broughty Ferry.Capital Cruising estimates that day-time stopover guests can spend as much as £ each on a visit – and overnight visitors can spend up to four times that amount.And with Dundee’s first post-VA summer to look forward to – and the Tay Cities Deal potentially leading to an all new Dundee Cruise Terminal – it’s full steam ahead for the city’s nautical ambitions.Mr Mason, pictured right, concluded: “If you look back to , we’d manage maybe two calls a year, but now we’re getting , .“The cruise ship business relies on good reviews soa customer has a good time and the cruise ship companies get good ratings they’re going to come back.“That’s why we’re happy to be working with our partners, like the trading associations and the council. The key thing is for us to bridge the gap between the port and the destination, through working with partners and local businesses.”

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s - win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: dundee couple who received 50000th baby box in scotland celebrate birth of baby boy
story: A Dundee couple who received the ,th baby box in Scotland have welcomed a baby boy to the world.Gary Phillips and Anna McFarlane had spoken of their shock when the box arrived in August containing the special message and described it as like “winning the golden ticket in Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory”.Six weeks later, little Rory McFarlane was born on Thursday September  weighing a healthy lb oz.The couple say he is doing well and thanked staff at Ninewells Hospital for their “unbelievable” help during the birth.They say they are excited to tell him he was a landmark baby when he grows up.Anna said: “We have the certicate saying he is the ,th baby to receive it still, so we will make sure he knows.”Gary said: “We’ve both been amazed at how useful all the items have been already. The bath thermometer in particular is just great for peace of mind.”The Scottish Government scheme was launched in August last year and sees “starter kits” sent to all expectant families four weeks prior to the mother’s due date. Each baby box contains a selection of clothes – from newborn to six months – as well as items including a travel changing mat, bib, bath towel, children’s books, bath room thermometer and a digital ear thermometer.

title: dundee gaffer neil mccann hoping lengthy injury list eases for crunch hamilton clash
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a - thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s - defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundee graduate who worked on outlander has film premiered at top scottish festival
story: A film-maker who worked on Outlander will have his first animated feature premiered at a top Scottish festival, after spending three years on its creation.Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design animation graduate Fraser Murdoch’s short, Tubgate: Cunningham’s Scrap, was made in collaboration with Dundee talent and will have its premiere at World of Film: International Festival Glasgow on Saturday.The freelance creative director, who has worked on numerous films, had been harbouring the idea for the short since his school days but only got the ball rolling on it in  while working in visual effects on the set of Outlander.Fraser said: “We try and play it in a way where there are jokes.“The aim of the film is to interact with the masses.“We’ve certainly pushed the boundaries on this project.”

title: dundee people prost beerfans flock tooktoberfest
story: Thousands of revellers descended on Slessor Gardens for the city’s biggest ever Oktoberfest.The annual event – which kicked off on Thursday – is back for its eighth year with a new home at the Waterfront site having outgrown its former home at Discovery Point.The Rotary Club of Dundee also showcased international food and drink as part of the celebrations.

title: dundee united sack manager csaba laszlo
story: Dundee United have parted company with manager Csaba Laszlo following yesterday#s - home thumping by Ross CountyThe club and Csaba have mutually agreed to end his contract effective today, with No  Laurie Ellis taking over on an interim basis.Dundee United chairman Mike Martin said: #I would like to thank Csaba for the considerable commitment he showed during his time at Dundee United and for his contribution to improving the underpinning football structure at the club.#We wish him all the best for the future. I can also confirm that Laurie Ellis has taken interim management responsibility for the team.#Ellis will likely be in the dugout for Saturday#s trip to face Ayr United in the Ladbrokes Championship as the Terrors look to appoint a replacement for Csaba.The Hungarian took up the post himself on November  last year and leaves the Tangerines sitting fourth in the table and five points behind leaders Ayr.

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make ato the city.The -times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November .Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance toto the national team at  years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park  years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although -years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September , a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in .The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No  shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet  Greet briefs – are on sale from am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.Help For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: exclusive laurie ellis to be given chance to become permanent dundee united boss
story: Caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is set to be given the chance to show he’s the man to lead Dundee United on a permanent basis.The Tangerines’ assistant boss has been put in interim charge following yesterday’s sacking of Csaba Laszlo.He’s expected to lead the team into Saturday’s clash with Championship leaders Ayr United at Somerset Park.And the -year-old could be given more games to show he should have the job on a permanent basis. vw, px"  Get today#s Tele for more on this story.

title: glasgow comedian limmy to return to dundee for two performances
story: Glasgow comedian Limmy is toto Dundee’s Rep Theatre next year.Real name Brian Limond, the Limmy’s Show star will introduce his new autobiography – Surprisingly Down to Earth, and Very Funny – on Sunday March  and Monday April .The Dundee shows are part of a UK tour which will include dates at Glasgow’s Oran Mor, Eden Court in Inverness and Aberdeen Arts Centre.The funnyman has been a frequent visitor to the city for several years with shows That’s Yer Lot and Limmy’s Vines.An advert for the tour reads: “Join Limmy for a night of anecdotes and chit-chat as he introduces his autobiography –Surprisingly Down to Earth, and Very Funny – featuring the true stories of how this permanent tripper ended up on the telly.”Tickets are available from dundeerep with doors open at .pm.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren - at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points andwe can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: local council cops flak for bogus advice on food vans near schools
story: Education chiefs in Fe have been accused of issuing bogus advice over what can be done to stop fast food vans setting up near schools.St Andrews councillor Jane Ann Liston has slammed Fe Council for its apparent failure to keep up to date on civic licensing issues in relation to food vans and schools.At present they limit the powers of local authorities to protect youngsters from eating too much of the wrong kind of food. The issue has come to light after the administration and education service insisted the region’s regulation and licensing committee had the power to keep mobile fast food outlets away from school gates.However, it has emerged a sherf overturned several burger van “exclusion zones” imposed by North Lanarkshire Council in , saying health was not a material consideration for civic licensing.Liberal Democrat Ms Liston said: “I am amazed Fe Council education service paid no attention to this pertinent judgment and was continuing to issue erroneous advice, apparently not noticing that regulation and licensing was no longer specying distances from schools when applications were made for hot food takeaway vans.“However, now they do know civic licensing cannot be used to protect the health of school pupils, the administration must lobby the government for the power to do so, perhaps through another avenue.“If they do not, then all talk about combating obesity in young people, from both Fe Council and Holyrood administrations, doesn’t amount to a row of beans.”The council stressed it will continue to work with the government and schools to promote healthy eating opportunities.

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a - home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a - thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first  minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing aafter getting  minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: particularly pleased va dundee chief responds to teles survey
story: The director of VA Dundee has welcomed the results of the Tele’s exclusive poll on locals’ first impressions of the museum.Nearly two-thirds of those who took part in the poll said they were happy with the public money that had been used to build and run the attraction.Forty per cent of respondents gave it full marks, with another % giving it nine out of  and % rating it as eight out of . vw, px"  Philip Long said he was happy to see the majority of readers giving the museum a positive score following its first two weeks of being open to the public.Mr Long, who took up his position as director seven years ago, added that he was “particularly pleased” to see people reacting positively to the museum’s groundbreaking design and the permanent collections.The world’s eyes were on Dundee as the city welcomed the VA earlier this month – and Mr Long, who told the Tele of his pride in the museum on opening day, said he was happy to see locals enjoyed it too.He said: “The opening of VA Dundee has been a hugely exciting moment for the city, with more than , people welcomed into the museum in its first week.“We’ve also seen huge international interest in Dundee’s regeneration and its rising profile as a destination for tourism and investment, which will help create more jobs in the city.“It’s great to see more than % of Eveningreaders giving VA Dundee  out of , and % of readers giving it a score of  out of  or higher.“I’m also particularly pleased to see the positive reaction to our permanent galleries, the look of the museum outside and the impact we will have on Dundee.”There will be opportunities for the public to review their opinion of VA Dundee – museum bosses call it a “living, evolving institution”.Mr Long previously said: “There will always be reasons for people to come and get involved.”

title: tennis clubs days may be numbered
story: The future of a Maryfield tennis club is set to be decided this week.Members of the Craigie Community Sports Hub will meet residents for further consultation on Wednesday evening.Craigmuir Tennis Club, on Dalkeith Road, first opened its doors in the s.It is believed the historic club’s days are numbered following discussion between residents and Craigie Community Sports Hub.Despite becoming one of four sports clubs involved in the hub several years ago, the courts haven’t had a single ball served on them in more than two years.Hub secretary George Allanconfirmed there would be a further discussions regarding the matter on Wednesday.He said the hub would make a full statement about the future of the club courts after the meeting.It’s understood the only viable option for the hub is to sell the land before reinvesting the money into other sports facilities in the local community.Craigie Community Sports Hub has already completed the development of a G pitch at Craigie High School and the adjacent pavilion.Speaking ahead of the meeting, Mr Allan said: “We don’t want to pre-empt anything until the consultation with the residents.“There is a meeting scheduled to take place on Wednesday evening.“Following that we will be making a full statement.”It is understood committee members from the hub surveyed the clubhouse and the courts in recent weeks before a decision was made for the potential sale of the land.Residents in neighbouring Dalkeith Road and Robson Street had spoken about the long–term future of the courts earlier this summer.Cameron Brown, , whose family moved into the area in , said previously he would “love” to see it reopened as a tennis court.

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s - win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had  players leave and  players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £ million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything  around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: youngsters bring dash of colour to dundee in art event
story: Youngsters brought dashes of colour to Reform Street over the weekend in a bid to create an “uplting” atmosphere in the city centre. vw, px"  Dozens of young people worked on designs at the Re-Formation live street art event on the thoroughfare’s cobbles on Saturday and Sunday.Co-ordinated by Dundee youth organisation The Corner, it was part of the Scottish Government’s Year of Young People .Most of the street was dedicated to designs worked on by those involved over the past four months, but space was also left for the public to have a go.Laura Cooney, community learning and development worker with The Corner, said one of the main design themes was chosen as mental health, as youngsters working on the project felt “really strongly” about the issue. There’s been so many people coming up and getting involved.”

title: Blainie 9 defies the odds in charity race
story: In , Blainie Whitewas diagnosed with a form of Batten disease which affects just eight people in the UK. It is a neurological condition which causes gradual loss of sight and movement, leaving the schoolgirl wheelchair-bound.The condition also causes Blainie to suffer from epilepsy.However, a team of dedicated family and friends have rallied round to raise money for specialist equipment which could transform her quality of le, and helped Blainie complete the Baxters River Ness KM race last Sunday.Her proud dad Scottsaid: ldquoThere was a full squad of us out doing the run and that was fantastic. It was really good for Blainie to be able to do it.ldquoShe was really enjoying all the noise and the music. You would never have thought that she would be able to do it, but she did.ldquoWe have raised nearly pound just through doing the run, which is brilliant.The family are raising money for a flotation device which will allow Blainie to swim, as well as a robust wheelchair to help her enjoy the great outdoors.ldquoShe just loves going in the pool, Mr White said.ldquoHowever, itrsquos between pound and pound for a device.ldquoWe are also looking at getting another wheelchair as well because we need one thatrsquos a bit bigger for when shersquos outside school.ldquoWe are always out doing walks which is another reason we need a more robust wheelchair for her.ldquoGetting out and about in the fresh air is something she really enjoys, but it also helps with her condition because it tires her out.ldquoSleep is so important becauseshe doesnrsquot get enough, that heightens the seizures.Blainiersquos cause is also being championed by the Royal Bank of Scotland, where three relatives work.The bankrsquos staff in Inverness have picked the Batten Disease Family Association as their chosen charity for next year.ldquoRBS have taken BDFA on as their charity of the year which is absolutely fantastic, Mr White added.ldquoMy partner Laura and her sister both work at the bank and her other sister is the manager so I just kept pestering them. Every year they have a charity they pick and for them to pick the BDFA is brilliant.ldquoAny money RBS raised will be doubled by the bank as well which is a huge bonus for us We are really grateful.Mr White says his daughter continues to inspire the family on a daily basis.ldquoShe canrsquot walk or talk any more, but she is always laughing and giggling, he said.ldquoShe does get a lot out of le. Shersquos an inspiration to us all.- To donate to Blainiersquos fund, visit justgiving crowdfunding littlebeesbattleTuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Entrance to Victorian Market to get facelift
story: WORKcould begin on the Victorian Marketrsquos makeover as early as January.Highland Council has submitted planning applications to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex, which dates back to .The plans involve bringing the glazed screen closer to the street in order to improve visibility into the market.The local authority says this will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points on Academy Street to one.An uplighting system is also set to be installed in order to highlight the historic architecture of the building, and signage will be removed to ldquo historic integrity to the Academy Street facade.The project marks the first stage of an action plan, which is being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund, which is also set to build a business case for the remodelling of the market hall.No timescale for the completion of the work has yet been finalised, but an application for a grant of pound, has been submitted to the Inverness Townscape Heritage project.The news of the redevelopment came just days after traders in the Queensgate Arcade section of the market spoke of their struggle to deal with ongoing issues with the complex roof.Businesses in the privately-owned section of the building have been forced to take action to deal with repeated leaks which have at times forced them to close.Toni Rutherford, of the Little Teapot cafe, believes businesses in the market need help to deal with the problem.ldquoIt is really frustrating for us that this problem keeps reappearing, she said.ldquoItrsquos not good, especially when you walk into the arcade and see all the buckets.ldquoItrsquos not a good impression for customers.ldquoWe understand that there will be issues with the age of the building but thatrsquos all the more reason to take care of it, especiallypeople are wanting to make all these improvements to the building.ldquoThree quarters of the building is owned by the council but the section we are in is privately owned.ldquoThat means that any issues with the roof in our section have to be dealt with by us as traders.ldquoThere have been times where we have had to close because of it. We have had waterfalls coming into the tearoom while customers have been in.ldquoAlthough dferent sections of the building are owned by dferent people we are all under one roof, so we feel there should be some help available for the situation.ldquoEveryone in the building needs to come together to get the problem solved.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Gay pride march to go ahead
story: A gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October , has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by  people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Horror over plan for hundreds of trucks to pass Inverness school
story: The six-month operation, which is due to begin next spring, would take the lorries via Cloverfield Road, the southern distributor route, B and onto the A.Contractor, forestry management company Scottish Woodlands, has told Highland Council it has reached agreement with a neighbouring farmer for a track to be upgraded to give lorries access to the woods.But local community figures say that does not address the issue of public safety.The firm says the work at Balvonie Woods is essential.Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis involves  truck journeys. To put that size of truck through a residential area, past Inshes Primary, is an unacceptable risk not to mention the disruption that could cause to the community. Some of the school community were horried at the prospect.Inverness South Community council secretary Bob Roberts said: ldquoNo matter what they do the lorries will pose problems.ldquoIrsquom very concerned for the pupilsrsquo safety because as well as this, at certain times of day the parking around the school is horrendous.The community council is still to formulate its official response to Highland Council.Scottish Woodlandsrsquo regional development manager Bruce Taylor said: ldquoItrsquos quite early days. Therersquoll be a consultation period from now until the end of the year and wersquoll look at all options.ldquo The point is to raise the proposal into the public arena and get responses with an expectation that we would be attending community council meetings to discuss the matter.ldquoAt the end of the day, the wood is becoming unsafe because there is wind-throw in it and we need to find a solution to it because the owner is becoming concerned that at some point somebody might get hurt by a fallen tree.Dates are still to be arranged for consultation events.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Inverness streets past preserved by key heritage trail
story: The new digital heritage trail, a key part of the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, spent the past two-and-a-half years engaging with the community around Academy Street.During that time some  heritage lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were held and people were invited to share their stories.In the end more than  came forward, representing people such as A. I. Welders Social Group, the Second Inverness Girls Brigade and the congregation and community of the East Church.Their input has brought to light a wealth of high quality content for the website, as well as opening up the rich iety of materials available in the cityrsquos museum, library and archive collections.And this new digital heritage trail was tested by stakeholders at Inverness Museum and Art Gallerylast week.Their feedback will help the developers, AOC Archaeology, refine and shape the website before it is launched on October .The site has been designed to continually evolve as more content is generated.A range of the results from the public engagement are currently on display at IMAG, including stunning detailed line drawings of Academy Street in  by Gordon Lynn.The Townscape Heritage Partnership chairman, Councillor Richard Laird, said: ldquoI am delighted to try out the website and to see how it showcases the rich iety of material that members of the public have so generously brought forward to save for generations of residents and visitors to our city.The project was run in partnership with High Le Highland and AOC Archaeology.Ian Murray, chief executive of High Le Highland, added: ldquoIt has been fascinating to hear the stories of Academy Street as told by over  iniduals who have generously contributed to the project.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Just get on with it Eastgate Hostel owners told
story: Pat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, said the owners should ldquostart now and stop making excuses after they said they were ldquofocusing  per cent on moving forward with plans to finally tackle the eyesore.Owners Imtaiz Ali and a Mr Cheng recently said they hoped a contract for demolition could be in place before the end of November, but work may not start until after the festive period to avoid inconveniencing neighbouring traders.In answer to further questions posed to them by the Courier, through agent Gary Johnston of GH Johnston Building Consultants, they also revealed more about their plans for the shop spaces and two holiday apartments set to be created when the building is restored.ldquoMr Cheng intends to reinstate his quality food takeaway restaurant, Mr Johnston said.ldquoThe other shop unit will be available for rent as a class one shop, restaurant, hot food takeaway or other business considered suitable in the town centre. This may require a further planning application to Highland Council.ldquoThe holiday apartments are aimed at visitors to Inverness and the Highlands and are commensurate with similar holiday lets in the High Street.ldquoAs the apartments will be new and with a generous floor area, they will be at the higher end of the quality lets.They owners said they would take ldquosoundings from Inverness Business Improvement District in terms of when would be the best time to start demolition work and refused to discuss why it had taken more than  days to get anything done.Mr Johnston said: ldquoThe owners will not make any comment on the past as they are now focusing  per cent on moving forward to get the scaffolding off the street and starting on the rebuild.But Mrs Hayden said she wanted to see action as soon as possible and there had been enough talk in the city about moving things forward.ldquoStart now and donrsquot use Christmas as an excuse. Get [the scaffolding] down. Todayrsquos a lovely day to start, she said.ldquoWersquove had enough excuses ndash Irsquom fed up of excuses.She said that when the fire happened her grand-daughter had been an infant, adding: ldquoThat grand-daughter is about to be seven. That puts it in perspective ndash itrsquos been far too long.ldquoAction is what is needed. Never mind consulting everybody ndash everyone in that area wants rid of the scaffolding.ldquoDonrsquot wait until after Christmas because then the weather will be bad and then therersquoll be another excuse.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Models needed for Inverness charity event
story: The event, to be held at Inverness Town House, is being organised by the Archie Foundation.It is looking for  males and  females aged over  and of all shapes and sizes with any connection to Raigmorersquos childrenrsquos unit or the foundation.They could include former patients and their families, or staff.The new childrenrsquos unit opened in  following a pound million appeal launched by the foundation in conjunction with The Inverness Courier.The foundation is now hoping to raise pound, for the Fresh Air project which will include fun features and topiary animals such as a ft Nessie.The fashion show will be held on Friday November  from pm to pm. It will be watched by about  people and include entertainment from TFX Performing Arts Academy.Jackie Cuddy, manager of the cityrsquos Eastgate Shopping Centre and a member of the foundationrsquos Highland fundraising committee, said no experience was necessary.ldquoWe are looking for people who have benefited from or been part of the work of this wonderful childrenrsquos facility helping to provide first class care for the children of the Highlands and Islands, she said.ldquoThis is a lsquorealrsquo fashion show for all ages over  and all shapes and sizes.ldquoIf there are families out there that have gone through a tough time recently, this experience could help to lt them and make them feel special. title: Pensioner pleads for help with poorly cat
story: An Inverness pensioner is appealing for help with her catrsquos medical treatment after discovering that her monthly pet plan does not cover the cost of an X-ray.Marie MacIverrsquos five-year-old cat Charlie has a painful leg and needs the scan to determine what treatment can be given.However, Mrs MacIver, who relies on disability benefit, is unable to afford the X-ray, which will cost about pound.She has now contacted themedia in a plea for kind-hearted Invernessians to come forward."There is no way I can afford to pay for the X-ray," she said."Since itrsquos very dficult for me to get out, I have already had to pay for the vet to come to the house and give Charlie a medical, as well as a bottle of anti-inflammatories which cost pound and did nothing."I already pay pound a month for a pet plan but it doesnrsquot seem to cover anything."I have tried everywhere to get help with the vetrsquos bills ndash the PDSA, RSPCA and Cats Protection, but I havenrsquot been able to get help from anywhere."I hate to see him in pain and I think itrsquos getting worse."It came out of the blue about a month ago, and now it is just not going away."Mrs MacIver lives alone with Charlie and says she has a special bond with her little cat."Hersquos my companion and is often the only company I have," she said."He sleeps on my bed and follows me into the kitchen, and he seems to know not to stray too far from the house because I need him."Hersquos really more like a dog than a cat."I try my best to take care of him but things like this are very dficult, and it is such a shame because he is a lovely little cat."I need to help Charlie get better."Can you help Mrs MacIver with the cost of Charliersquos X-ray  Email us via newsdesk@spp-groupTuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Response to Charlie tale stuns cat owner
story: Marie MacIver, who lives in Hilton and relies on disability benefit, lives alone with her five-year-old cat Charlie.She got in touch with the Courier after it became apparent that Charliersquos injured leg needed an X-ray, which she could not afford.She had already contacted animal welfare charities without success.After we printed the story last week, we were inundated with offers of help for little Charlie ndash and Mrs MacIver admitted she was moved to tears.ldquoI donrsquot know what I would have done without everyone who offered to help, she said.ldquoIrsquove been in tears because people have been so nice. I had a card from a lady wishing me and Charlie all the best. That was such a touching thing for someone to do.ldquoThe card has pride of place on my mantelpiece.ldquoPeople are just so kind, even to a poor little animal like Charlie.ldquoSome people would see him as just a cat but to me he is much more than that.ldquoI just want to say thank you so much to everyone who has been in touch wanting to help. I didnrsquot think anything would come of it.Local cat owner Ian Aird came to Mrs MacIverrsquos aid, donating enough money to cover the cost of the X-ray, leaving her gobsmacked.ldquoI canrsquot thank Ian enough, she said.ldquoIt was so kind of him to do that for me and Charlie.ldquoIrsquom so incredibly grateful to Ian. I have no words that can describe how grateful I am for what he has done.Mr Aird said: ldquoI am a cat owner myself and when I read the story I felt so much sympathy for Mrs MacIver.ldquoShe is an elderly lady and she doesnrsquot get out of the house very much so thatrsquos why I thought it was important that I helped her.ldquoFor someone in her position, Charlie is often her only companion.ldquoThis situation seems to have resonated with a lot of people, particularly cat owners around Inverness.Charlie has now been diagnosed with patellar dysplasia, where the kneecap is slightly misshapen, and requires no further treatment other than keeping weight off his leg.ldquoIrsquom so relieved itrsquos nothing serious, Mrs MacIver added.ldquoBut I have taken out an insurance plan, and I would encourage everyone  to do the same in case something like this happens again.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: Star honour for city cadet
story: Euan Stewart from st Battalion the Highlandersrsquo Inverness detachment has been appointed the battalionrsquos new Cadet Regimental Sergeant Major .The -year-old who joined the youth organisation five years ago is being championed for his long list of achievements.Graeme Wells from the army cadet force said the high flying cadet has climbed right up the ranks to completed his Master Cadet, which is the highest a cadet can reach.On top of his cadet achievements he has also had the honour of being the Lord Lieutenantrsquos Cadet of Inverness-shire.This position allowed him to assist the Lord Lieutenant of Inverness-shire, Donald Cameron of Lochiel, in his duties as Her Majesty The Queenrsquos appointed representative for the area.Mr Wells said Mr Stewart was also an ldquoexcellent shooter who has represented the battalion on several occasions in regional and national shooting competitions, including the Inter-Service Cadet Rle meeting at Bisley Ranges in Surrey.Last year he scooped the battalion its first trophy in this contest, coming in first in the Patriotic  competition.Mr Wells added: ldquoEuan was promoted to his new position at Fort George last Saturday while taking part in training for the upcoming Scottish Cadet Military Skills Competition in which he has been named as the teamrsquos Section Commander.Mr Stewart, who is a Culloden Academy pupil and has his heart set on studying mechanical engineering at university, said he was delighted with the honour.He said: ldquoMy brother Andrew was originally in the cadets and he achieved a high level so that inspired me and we also have connections with the Honorary Colonel Councillor Carolyn Caddick whose son was the last RSM so and I guess I was quite inspired by him too.Tuesday  Oct  : AM

title: scotland squad
story: Aberdeen#s Scott McKenna and Graeme Shinnie have been named in Alex McLeish#s Scotland squad.The Reds duo are in the group of  selected to face Israel in Haa on Thursday, October  in the Nations League Group C fixture and Portugal in a friendly at Hampden three days later.Defender McKenna, who has four caps, s to the squad after missing the last two internationals against Belgium and Albania through injury. The -year-old captained the Dark Blues against Mexico in June during the summer tour of Central and South America.Meanwhile Pittodrie captain Shinnie, who has two caps, keeps his place in Gothenburg Great McLeish#s squad after featuring as a sub in last month#s friendly against Belgium.Dons# winger Gary Mackay-Steven misses out on selection, despite a strong start to the season.Former Aberdeen winger Ryan Fraser, now with English Premier League Bournemouth, has also been named in the squad.

title: sign our petition to change time of aberdeen semi final clash at hampden4
story: Dons fans have branded the decision to make Aberdeen’s League Cup semi-final against Rangers at Hampden a noon kick-off “an absolute disgrace”.Supporters’ groups, the club and Hearts have all hit out after it was revealed both semi-finals would be played at the national stadium in Glasgow on the same day.And now the Evening Express has launched a petition in an effort to make the SPFL reconsider the ridiculous scheduling of the Aberdeen v Rangers League Cup semi-final on Sunday October .The lunchtime kick-off is an outrageous time for fans from the north-east to get to Hampden – and scheduling the Hearts v Celtic semi on the same day at the same venue only compounds the problem.Sign this petition to send a message to the SPFL that’s loud and clear: This showpiece fixture MUST be changed to a new venue or time for the sake of the fans.

title: aberdeen out of school club praised by inspectors
story: An Aberdeen out of school club has been lavished with praise in a recent report.Great Western OOSC @ Holburn West was given the highest possible mark following an unannounced inspection.The Care Inspectorate awarded the club excellent in the quality of care and support and the quality of management and leadership.One parent told inspectors their children are “very happy there, therefore we in turn are happy with their care”.Inspectors last reviewed the city centre club in , where it was awarded two good and two very good grades.The report said: “We saw her display excellent leadership skills and role modelling throughout the inspection.“Any concerns raised by parents or incidents that arose at the club were fully explored with a clear focus on supporting the best possible outcomes for the children and working in partnership with parents.”

title: survey 99 on board for skate park
story: Nearly % of respondents to a study have thrown their weight behind skate park plans.As part of a feasibility study, % of people said they would be happy for the skate park to be built in Banchory.The group behind the plans was given the green light in May to seek a lease for the land at Bellfield Park by the Marr Area Committee.Due to the nature of the land, Banchory Skatepark Groupwould need to gain a lease from a sherf before starting to build.BSG was tasked with producing a feasibility study as part of the application to the sherf.Russ Crichton, chairman of the BSG, said: “The feasibility study covered many areas but of particular interest was the community consultation.“The consultation threw up a fantastic result and very supportive comments.“Overall there were  responses with .% support to a new skate park in Banchory.“We are now completing the specication to issue out to Public Contracts Scotland to gather bids for the new skate park.“We are also continuing to develop the design and preparation for our planning application which will take place in the next few weeks.”The consultation asked respondents  questions about the skate park, covering topics from the local need for the development to the possibility of a fee being charged for use.If the fee were to be introduced, the report says, it may only be applicable at night, and will primarily be used to fund a “pay as you go” floodlight system.Respondents decided £ per hour was a fair price to charge for the lighting.Almost three-quartersof respondents said that floodlighting should be part of the facility.The cost of the project is estimated at £,, % of which will be matched by the Banchory Developers Fund.

title: work on revamp of aberdeens union terrace gardens may not start this year1
story: Tenders to redevelop Union Terrace Gardens will close in the middle of this month, it has been revealed.Aberdeen City Council has still to appoint a contractor for the multi-million-pound revamp of the Victorian gardens and is accepting bids to carry out the work until later in the month.Douglas Lumsden, co-leader of the local authority, has not been able to give assurances the work – due to be completed in  – will kick off this year, but has said it “hopes” to appoint a contractor by the end of the year.SNP group leader Stephen Flynn has raised concerns over perceived delays to the work.He said: “We’re all well aware that Union Terrace Gardens is behind schedule and the key thing at this stage is the administration ensure their revised timetable is kept to.“We can’t afford any further slippage.#Construction has yet to start, but without a spade yet hitting the ground it is feared it may be impossible for the ambitious project to be completed within the estimated - to -month timeframe.Mr Lumsden said: “We’ve made it clear that we’re in the tender process just now and it’s just typical of the opposition trying to talk the city down when they should be getting behind the projects we’re putting in place.”A number of high-profile council projects have been delayed in recent years, including revamps of Broad Street, the art gallery, Provost Skene’s House and the Central Library.London Olympic Park architects LDA Design won planning permission for its Union Terrace Gardens plan in March.The proposals include new walkways, an amphitheatre and a cafe.They aim to conserve the Victorian park’s heritage and to “sustain Aberdeen’s performance in times of economic dficulty”, according to a design statement.Other features of the scheme include a new accessible walkway route into the gardens from Union Street.Lt access from Union Street into the upper level of the gardens will also be provided through a new entrance building on Union Terrace at the existing Burns Monument.The central lawn space would be retained as a flexible space for large-scale gatherings and events and there would be a new entrance opposite His Majesty’s Theatre.The plans mark the latest development in the future of the city park. Councillors rejected proposals for a £ million transformation of the gardens in .Businessman Sir Ian Wood had offered £m towards the cost and earlier this year claimed it was a “tragedy” Aberdeen City Council decided to reject his multi-million-pound plan for the renovation of the gardens.

title: gap should be broader to win two in borders
story: Aberdeen Grammar came within two minutes of a Border double at Selkirk, only to have the game cruelly snatched away from them.Home flanker Sean Nixon crashed over the Rubislaw outfit’s line to tie up the scores at  points apiece.Worse was to come for the visitors when winger Frazer Anderson slotted the touchline conversion, making it a perfect day for the player who kicked all of his four attempts at goal in the last-gasp - win.Grammar head coach Ali O’Connor was understandably gutted at the conclusion of a game his side had controlled for most of the  minutes.They went into the last quarter leading - on the back of four tries, scored by stand-off Sam Knudson, flanker Alex Dravitski, scrum-half Cairan Wood and winger Nat Coe.O’Connor said: “It was hard to take, particularly as we had the lion’s share of the game, and dominated up front.“Normally I would be happy to have taken seven points of a possible  against two Border sides, including Kelso last week.“But we must learn to close out games, and not be too flamboyant going into the closing stages of a game we have seemingly won.“There were, however, some outstanding performances, including first-rate showings from Ewan Stewart, Chris Jollands and captain Sam Knudson.”Playing into a stf first-half breeze, Grammar did not make the best of the conditions, only taking a - lead into the break.But early in the second half two well-taken tries, both converted by Knudson, saw them apparently on their way.But the Borderers had other ideas, battling back with touchdowns of their own to snatch an unlikely victory.In Glasgow, Gordonians kept up their unbeaten run, easing past Hillhead Jordanhill - to the satisfaction of head coach Ryan Morrice.He said: “This is the kind of game we would have lost last season, but we have learned how to keep our composure and stick to the game plan.“The win has set us up nicely for a tilt at leaders Newton Stewart at Countesswells. The try bonus point was very welcome. We are in a good place.”The Gordonians tries were scored by Matt Hillier, Danny Usugo, David Ilyine and Chris Simpson. Full-back Graeme Crawford kicked a conversion and a penalty.At the Meadows, newly-promoted Ellon ran out convincing - winners against derby rivals Aberdeen Wanderers, earning them bragging rights in the Caley Division  clash.Head coach Craig Parslow said: “We have a great team ethic, everyone is playing for each other.”

title: letters to the editor week 34
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.Sir,The decision of Argyll and Bute Council to allow expansion of Poll na Gille and BDNC Loch Shuna is reprehensible.These sites have been named as being the first and third worst respectively of all the salmon farms in Scotland on an index of welfare and health measures, including premature death rates, sea lice numbers, escapes, breaches of biomass limits and seal shooting .Despite the above, there was a decision made by Argyll and Bute planning department that Environmental Impact Assessments were not required for the expansion of either of these fish farms.The Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform committee report on the environmental impacts of salmon farming stated, in a letter dated March , , to the Rural Economy and Connectivity committee that: #The committee is supportive of aquaculture, but further development and expansion must be on the basis of a precautionary approach and must be based on resolving the environmental problems.  The status quo is not an option.#It is apparent that Argyll and Bute Council does not intend to adopt the precautionary approach recommended, but continues to agree to unsustainable expansion, even at locations which are in breach of the current standards required.Christine Richards, Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,We would like to invite your more adventurous readers to join us on our Lake District challenge next spring and help save lives and rebuild futures shattered by meningitis.They will conquer eight peaks, all above , feet, over two days. It will require energy, commitment and a positive attitude, but will reward those taking part with breath-taking views, wrapped up in a serious adventure and a weekend they’ll never forget – there’s a great team spirit amongst those taking part and many come away from the challenge having made lelong friends.Every step they take will also help us to fight meningitis and move us closer to our vision of a future where no one in the UK dies from this devastating disease and everyone affected gets the support they need.Registration is just £, with a fundraising pledge of £. Accommodation, food, travel and the support of a qualied and experienced mountain leader and safety team are all included, and I#ll be there to support you throughout your fundraising journey. It takes place between Thursday May  and Sunday May  next year.Find out more at www.MeningitisNow.org or by emailing me at michaelai@meningitisnow.org .Michaela Ifill, Meningitis NowSir,The World#s Biggest Coffee Morning event is fast approaching and we would love for readers in Argyll and Bute to get involved.Having become a national institution since it launched in , it has raised millions to help change the lives of people living with cancer, including here in Argyll and Bute.Last year some , people said that they were planning on taking part in homes, workplaces and schools across the country # but the idea remains as simple as ever: come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support.Cancer can affect every aspect of a person’s le, from their day-to-day living and relationships to their finances and mental health. Macmillan is there to help people with cancer live le as fully as they can.Offering a broad range of cancer information and support services # including a free support line and a community of over , healthcare professionals # demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing, but we rely on the generosity of the public to provide this support.Macmillan’s Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September  # but people can host whenever they want. Whoever they invite and whatever they serve, people are highly encouraged to host a Macmillan Coffee Morning in a way that suits them.If people can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop them. Throughout September, headline partner MS will be selling a selection of limited edition coffee morning products # including lots of cakes, biscuits and two exclusive mugs # with  per cent of proceeds going to Macmillan.Homes, workplaces and communities from the Shetland Islands to Land’s End will be hosting coffee mornings this year readers in Argyll and Bute can find events nearby using the interactive map on the Coffee Morning website www.macmillan.org.uk coffee.Thank you to everyone who gets involved.Joanna Lumley, actress and Macmillan supporterSir,The SNP announced it is starting up a new #fact-checking# service to monitor the accuracy of research and political statements.Many people in Scotland will be wonderingthe SNP will be fact-checking the cost of its new independence blueprint. Analysis has continually shown that an independent Scotland would mean cuts to public spending and increased taxes.The SNP now has to answer serious questions about the real cost of independence as the latest GERS figures will once again show how much we benefit from being part of the UK. It#s time for the separatists to be honest and accept the facts.With Labour embroiled in a new scandal almost every second day and the LibDems disappearing into irrelevance it#s clear that only Ruth Davidson#s Scottish Conservatives can stand up to Nicola Sturgeon#s IndyRef obsession.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of Islay

title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals asfashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, eventhey don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in , a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now,  years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per celland the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.

title: letters to the editor week 37
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.Sir,It is always a delight when a letter awakens a landowner.James F Lithgow#s insult about ‘blow-ins’ is a typical trait. I worked extremely hard to buy my farm, not being able to piggyback on my forebears’ efforts, and I didn’t ‘blow-in’, it took two forty-foot pantechnicons four days.It is clear he has an interest in wind turbines, and no doubt with a pair of wellies, a fish farm or two. His blinkered refusal to accept the huge body of evidence regarding fish farm contamination suggests he has an investment and it needs protecting. But only, of course,you don’t have a commercial interest.There is a huge amount of evidence that mechanical kelp harvesting does irreparable damage to the sea bed. Could I draw your readers# attention to the Facebook page #Stop Mechanical Kelp Dredging# The sea bed can’t be seen, but a bank statement can. No prizes for who is the loser. The  jobs in aquaculture will not last longmass kelp harvesting is allowed to decimate sub-sea environments and the only jobs on fish farms will be pushing barrows of diseased and dead fish.I’ve no doubt he knows that wind turbines have a -year le span and then the hugely disruptive process will start againan alternative has not been discovered. It has been calculated that the energy costs of a wind turbine will never be recovered during its lespan, but those receiving grants really don’t care.Why, given the amount of rainfall in Argyll, are hydro schemes not pursued  It used to be a mystery, until one looks at the vast sums of subsidy given by a gullible government to so called ‘alternative energy sources’, which actually means ‘alternative revenue sources’.There are any number of pretty glens that could be dammed, providing an extra environmentally-friendly leisure resource, create an opportunity for aquaculture and would not require a replacement somewhere down the line.Alexander Hamilton, Tayvallich.Sir,With reference to James Lithgow’s letter of September , it is important to make a couple of points.Mr Lithgow is right to say kelp has been sustainably harvested in Argyll for generations. There can be no comparison, however, with the current proposal to mechanically dredge up entire stands from the seabed together with all the fragile le that depends on them. This is not sustainable as evidenced in the few countries which have allowed this practice to take place.  Seaweed cultivation, on the other hand, is sustainable and more can be found on this through the Scottish Association for Marine Science.The  parliamentary inquiry into the environmental impact of salmon farming warned current methods could cause #irrecoverable damage#.  This is deeply concerning to those of us who live here, raise families and rely on the sea for our creel fishing, shellfish and tourism businesses. We also all have an inherent responsibility to care for our environment and there is increasing urgency to do this.Enterprises do need to be encouraged to grow and to provide opportunities and employment. This, however, must be done responsibly and with thought for the long-term viability of our communities.The profits of the predominantly multi-national salmon farming companies, who benefit from current loopholes in our environmental regulations, are well able to fund a responsible and researched approach for sustainability and erse employment opportunities. Norway, for example, is encouraging its salmon farmers to adopt closed containment and these methods are working well in a number of other countries, including the USA.The council has a legal responsibility for the environment and needs to take precautions for the future of Argyll, not just for job numbers today.If short-term interests are prioritised, all of our futures will be much the poorer.Will Self, on behalf of Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,Most schools in Scotland have pipers and drummers within their pupil population.Schools in Argyll are probably no exception. May I please ask your readers to seek out their pipers and encourage them to represent their school as a piping quartet,not as a full band, at the next Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships The championships are organised annually by the Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trust. The next championships will be held at Inveralmond Community High School, Livingston, on Sunday March  .More details are on our website # www.thechampionships.Last March,  schools from Scotland and two from England were represented at the championships, with a category for all standards of playing.Five years ago we introduced a new category of #freestyle#.  The aim of this is to provide an opportunity for schools to showcase their other musical skills alongside those of their pipers.The Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trusthopes many young pipers and drummers from Mid Argyll # with other musicians tooentering the freestyle event – will participate in next year’s championships.Patrick Gascoigne, administrator, Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships.
