story: Where therersquos a wheel there will soon be a way.Round-the-world cyclist Mark Beaumont has given his backing to an ambitious project to link two Ross-shire towns by a cycle and walkway.The Peffery Way Association is creating a route between Dingwall and Strathpeffer for foot and cycle traffic, as an alternative to the potentially dangerous main road.It has so far raised pound, and the first .km of the total km link is set to be completed soon.The next stage will cover km between Dingwall and Fodderty, but because conditons make construction costs much more expensive on this section around pound, is needed.It is hoped around pound, of this will come from ious Scottish Government grants, with decisions expected on these around Christmas.Mr Beaumont, who holds the record for cycling round the world has now given his backing to the project.At a talk at Eden Court in Inverness earlier this month he screened a three-minute video produced by the projectrsquos charity.Chairman Ron Macauley, who was in the audience, said: "It was a fantastic endorsement of what we are trying to do."I spoke to him afterwards and he thinks the project is a great idea and wished us all the best."I said he should come and try it when it is open ndash but he would probably do it in two minutes!"The beauty of the Peffery Way is that we can build a path that is accessible by all. If you look around the Highlands we are blessed with the most beautul scenery, but much of it can be hilly."This would provide a km path with no steep climbs or gradients and that could be a unique feature ndash certainly unique for around here."Mr Macauley said pound, in total would be needed to complete the project, which he hoped would be possible "in a few years."Planning permission and landowner agreement have recently been granted for the next stage and an application for finance has been lodged with the Scottish Rural Development Fund .Mr Macauley said: "It is an excellent project with a lot of potential to bring a lot of good to the community. It will be a safe corridor for people to walk and cycle and help people avoid going on a dangerous road."Highlands and Islands MSP Maree Todd said she strongly supported the project because "absolutely everyone in the community can get out and enjoy nature."She said: "I think the Peffery Way will become a vital link between Strathpeffer and Dingwall and all the communities in between."The path is both offroad and flat ndash two huge advantages."It will be a fantastic asset for travel to school and work or just for visiting pals."To find out more about the project and donate see www.pefferywayassociation.scotTuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Fortrose Co op plan sparks objection from community council
story: If given the go-ahead by Highland Council planners, the new supermarket would be located on a greenfield site behind Ness Lodge on the junction of Ness Road, Rosemarkie Road and the High Street.Co-op Food is confirmed as the main tenant, and would occupy a  sq ft building ndash a big increase on the existing  sq ft store in Fortrosersquos High Street. It is thought the smaller site would closethe new store went ahead, although Co-op Food had not responded by the time the Ross-shire Journal went to print.The applicant, Northquest Ltd, has also earmarked two further building plots for possible future development within the proposed storersquos grounds ndash another  sq ft building and one covering  sq ft.The store would be accessed via Ness Road and have parking for  cars and two motorbikes. The access road also features a bell-shaped junction at its far end, opening up the possibility that nearby land may also be developed in the futurethe site went ahead.The Fortrose and Rosemarkie Community Council has unanimously opposed the proposals, citing concerns over its location within a designated buffer zone that is designed to keep Fortrose and Rosemarkie from merging into one.Chairman Tom Heath said the community council felt the application fell foul of two elements of the local development plan, the first of which was its location.He added: ldquoThe second is that we were concerned of the effects it would have on the rest of the High Street and the viability of the remainder of the businesses on High Street [ it relocated].Those reactions have been shared by some residents, who have been responding to a consultation launched by the community council.While many welcomed the prospect of a larger Co-op store and greater iety on its shelves, others raised fears that the existing High Street shoprsquos off-street car park could be lost in the move ndash forcing cars to park on the main road and putting greater pressure on this notorious traffic bottleneck.Others shared the community councilrsquos argument that the development is on land zoned as off-limits in the local development plan.Fears had been raised that a decision last year by Highland councillors to approve a new poundmillion care home within this buffer zone would set a precedent that opened up the wider area to development. It was passed despite the objection of planning officers.And this concern was shared by some of the public.Responding on Facebook to the community councilrsquos call for comment, Gail Paterson said: ldquoIt will kill Fortrose High Streetallowed. The care homehas set a precedent so canrsquot see how this can be knocked back and from there on in the land will go to housing without the infrastructure being sorted out.Bridget Gerstner added: ldquoThe shop would be nice but not there. This is the foot in the door. Once we agree to this site, there will be no stopping building on the land between Fortrose and Rosemarkie.Mr Heath said the community council had taken fears over the care homersquos impact on the buffer zone to council officers last year, and that they had been given assurances that its approval would not set a precedent.- Share your view. title: Highland Council blasted over carbon data bungle
story: HIGHLAND Council chiefs have admitted bungling their quest to cut the local authorityrsquos carbon emissions.They have confessed to gaps in data-recording over the past three years which have made it impossible to get a grip on the scale of the output.Planning director Stuart Black, who oversees the process, gave the councilrsquos audit and scrutiny committee a pledge it would not be allowed to happen mdash for a fourth successive year.The council must comply with a UK-wide ldquocarbon reduction commitment efficiency scheme before that is abolished next April and replaced with a climate change levy. A report to councillors explained how monitoring of public buildings fitted with solar  was incomplete and that some ldquodata was calculated for two sites that had actually been deleted from the process the previous year.Worse still, despite previous agreed management action, ldquono record of eligible sites has been established, the report stated. It added: ldquoThere is no definitive site list. There is no robust system in place to capture meter readings for renewable energy from photovoltaic solar .Mr Black offered an apology for the auditrsquos revelations.Council leader Margaret Davidson told colleagues: ldquoOur carbon emissions are more than they should be and itrsquos costing us a lot of money. That canrsquot be changed unless wersquove got accurate management and record keeping.She said she would request that officials review the processes, how decisions are made within the relevant department and the scrutiny of the work it does.Speaking afterwards, councillor Roddy Balfour, a colleague in the minority independent administration said it amounted to ldquogross incompetence.He said he hoped the audit and scrutiny committee, which is chaired by opposition SNP councillor Graham MacKenzie, would ensure that the issues would be urgently addressed and keep the council within national guidelines associated with climate change policies.Highlands and Islands Green MSP John Finnie, a former councillor, said: ldquoThe councilrsquos latest bungle is seriously concerning. Itrsquos failed to collect data which is necessary to assess its contribution to tackling climate change. A commitment that lsquoit would not be allowed to happen for a fourth successive yearrsquo is cold comfort. It should not have been allowed to get to this stage.ldquoPerhaps I shouldnrsquot be surprised. When the council does collect information it regularly ignores it ndash all too evident in the shambles that is their public toilet closure plan. Letrsquos hope the appointment of a new chief executive will bring a renewed focus on evidencing decisions, by both collecting the appropriate evidence and acting on it.Tuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Mini theme for Black Isle art competition
story: CREATIVE talents from across the Black Isle are being urged to throw their hat into their ring following the launch of an annual arts competition.The Cromarty Arts Trust has called all amateur and non-professional artists to put their pieces forward for consideration in the Creative Cromarty competition.Entries can be within the mediums of painting, drawing, photography or D model sculpture."The competition is a great way to get your artwork out there and to help amateurs develop their skill set and confidence," said a spokesman for the trust. This yearrsquos theme is lsquoMiniature Worldrsquo which invites artists to view their surroundings, environment or even objects up close and personal."The goal of the theme is to challenge local artists to try something new and to give their take on what the brief means to them."Since this is the lsquoYear of Young Peoplersquo, the trust hopes that the theme will encourage people of all ages to produce something unique but especially hopes that local young people will be inspired to get creative."The competition is open to primary school pupils and adults.There will be three prizes up for grabs, one for primary school entrants and two for adults according to the medium in which they submitted their work. They will receive hand-made, wooden trophies created specically for the competition by local artist, James Flavell.Entries will also be displayed at The Stables in Cromarty on December  and will be open to the public to come and view.The competition is open to people who live within the Fortrose Academy catchment area on the Black Isle. Only piece of artwork per person will be accepted.Entries must be submitted by pm on Friday, November .To find out more visit www.cromartyartstrust.org.uk or pick up an info pack from Cromarty or Fortrose Library.Tuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Muir hall set for 250k makeover
story: A pound, revamp of a Ross-shire village hall at the heart of the community it serves for  years is under way with hopes high the work will give it a fresh start.The work centres on Muir of Ord village hall which has benefited from funding from a number of sources.Work on the refurbishment project was awarded by the Muir of Ord Hall and Facilities Company to Compass Building and Construction Services.Work started on the revamp last week and with a scheduled completion by the end of this year.The focus of the work is on the insulation of the building including the replacement of windows and doors. Also scheduled is a revamp of the heating system to make it more economic and efficient and modernisation of the toilets.Additional space for rental is also part of the plans. A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoWe anticipate that these refurbishments should enable a much better experience for the many users of the village hall and also encourage greater use of the facility.A budget of around pound, has been set aside for the work which has been primarily raised from three sources mdash the Highland Council, SSErsquos energy efficiency fund and Fairburn wind farm fund and the Highland Cross.The spokeswoman added: ldquoThe Muir of Ord Hall and Facilities Company is very grateful for these contributions and some local donations, without which we would not have been able to proceed.The Muir of Ord Village Hall on Seaforth Road has been a community hub for the village since . In , following the Highland Councilrsquos decision to est itself of the building, a public meeting agreed that the community should take on ownership of the resource.An option appraisal committed the community association to establish a separate company limited by guarantee to hold the ownership of the hall. The Muir of Ord Hall  Facilities Company was set up in April  and bought the hall from the council for pound in May .It was accepted at the time thatit was ever to cover its own costs, a refurbishment would be required. title: Nepal quest a fascinating subject at Gairloch talk
story: But the subject of the presentation at Gairlochrsquos Gale Centre will not be the Highlands of Scotland, however, but the Dolpo-pa ndash the indigenous yak herding tribes of the Himalayan peaks.Gavin Anderson, from Ullapool, has spent more than  years working in international development which has included researching how the people of north-west Nepal could benefit from adventure tourism often solely fixated on Mount Everest and Annapurna areas.He spent time with the Dolpo-pa, in snow leopard country, and discovered how tourism had passed them by due to inaccessibility and poor infrastructure.Drawing on experiences of developing enterprises in both remote Scotland and around the globe, he developed Nomadic Skies Expeditions ndash a tourism company aimed at harnessing and developing the skills of the native Nepalese villagers.Not only will attendees learn how Gavinrsquos company plans to help build a new economic future for these people, listeners can also play their part by joining one of the tours in .ldquoThere are many parallels between the highlands of Scotland and the seldom visited valleys of the High Himalaya of north-west Nepal. Essentially, both need to have sustainable ways of making a living to avoid the young people moving away, and ensure that the unique culture survives, Gavin says.ldquoWhat I will be looking at in the talk, as well as giving an insight into le amongst the turquoise lakes and snow-capped peaks, is how Nomadic Skies Expeditions will attempt to test a whole new form of tourism that will benefit these remote cultures.ldquoHow can we prevent the negative and unintended consequences of tourism and make sure the local benefits are maximised  I am sure people will have their own views, from the Scottish perspective and it will be good to hear them.ldquoPeople will also be given the opportunity to be part of the journey with us.The talk will take place in the Gale Centre in Gairloch next Thursday, October  at .pm.For more details about Mr Andersonrsquos tours visit www.nomadicskiesThe  day expeditions start and finish in Kathmandu and typically feature no more than eight to  people, accompanied by Mr Anderson and a local Nepalese guide. The route climbs to as high as , feet, taking in the likes of Ringmo by the famous Phoksundo Lake , as well as the high yak pastures and rock fields above that location.The route is on relatively good paths but with some steep ascents and exposure in places.That, coupled with the high altitude and lower oxygen levels, means that those looking to take part in any of next yearrsquos expeditions should have a good level of health and fitness and experience of walking.Tuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Tuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Student weaves her way into the world of textiles
story: A WEAVER from Invergordon is sew delighted after graduating from a fashion and textiles school which bears the name of the worldrsquos largest fashion and luxury group.Mairi MacLeod, a former pupil of Invergordon Academy, enrolled on an intensive eight-week training course in developing sewing skills and finished products, which took place in the LVMH Textile Training Centre at Dumfries House near Cumnock.It was run by The Prince of Walesrsquo charity The Princersquos Foundation. The course aims to equip students with the practical skills and knowledge needed to gain employment in Scotlandrsquos world-famous textiles industry and complements an existing schools programme, Future Textiles, that has been running for four years.Future Textiles has been running for four years and aims to breathe fresh talent into Scotlandrsquos fashion and textiles industry.The -year-old, who met HRH The Prince of Wales the day she graduated, initially applied for a place on the course to learn how to design products and sew to industry standards. She explained: "Before joining the course, I worked as a costume assistant in Glasgow but didnrsquot know much about sewing or manufacturing clothes and felt like it would be a great opportunity for me to learn."I loved every minute of the course and learned so much as the tutors were very hands-on and the class was small."Through the course, Irsquove been introduced to many people in the industry which has been great. Irsquom very interested in sustainability in fashion and being on this course has inspired me to seek employment in the Scottish textiles industry."On completion of the course, Mairi was presented with a certicate of achievement from The Great British Sewing Beersquos Patrick Grant and leading Scottish textiles manufacturer John Sugden, who are co-chairs of The Princersquos Foundationrsquos Future Textiles steering group.She said: "It was great to meet Patrick Grant and John Sugden as they are both incredibly knowledgeable about fashion and textiles. They took the time to chat to us and were very encouraging."Jacqueline Farrell, education director at The Princersquos Foundation at Dumfries House, said: "In the British textiles industry, there is currently a huge demand for skilled employees. The courses run by The Princersquos Foundation at The LVMH Textile Training Centre exist not only to equip trainees like Mairi with the practical skills they need but also to connect them with industry professionals."As part of the course, the Mairi undertook a work placement with designer Christopher Raeburn in London and everyone was very impressed with her talent and work ethic."Tuesday  Oct  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
